Title: Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Suprascapular and Interscalene Nerve Blocks in Shoulder Arthroscopy

Background: This study aimed to compare the analgesic efficacy and safety of suprascapular nerve block (SSNB) versus interscalene brachial plexus block (ISB) in patients undergoing shoulder arthroscopy.

Methods: A meta-analysis of 17 randomised controlled trials (RCTs) involving 1255 patients was conducted. Participants were adults undergoing shoulder arthroscopy, with eligibility criteria including the use of SSNB or ISB. The primary outcome was postoperative pain, measured using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) at various time points. Randomisation and allocation concealment were adequately described in 15 and 16 studies, respectively. Blinding of outcome assessors was reported in all studies.

Results: 1255 patients were randomised, with 17 RCTs analysed. SSNB resulted in higher VAS at rest in PACU (MD = 0.56, 95% CI [0.19, 0.94], P = 0.003) but lower VAS at 12 hours post-operation (MD = −0.71, 95% CI [−1.12, −0.3], P = 0.0006). No significant difference in oral morphine use at 24 hours (P = 0.35). SSNB had fewer complications, including Horner syndrome (P < 0.0001) and dyspnea (P = 0.04).

Interpretation: SSNB offers a safe alternative to ISB with similar pain control and fewer complications. Further RCTs with long-term follow-up are needed. Trial registration: CRD42020205426. Funding: Not specified.
